docs.lead_paragraph: RUSH hour is not a great time to be trying to get from Times Square to Columbus Circle on the Nos. 1 or 9 trains. Not in July. Not if you're pregnant. And certainly not if you are expecting twins. But that was the point. Would the spectacle of what looks like -- and indeed is -- considerable discomfort in a fellow traveler provoke from subway riders a show of sympathy? How long would it take for pity to kick in and a seat to be offered up?

headline.main: Metro Matters; Sampling The Kindness Of Strangers

docs.abstract: Elizabeth Kolbert Metro Matters column discusses her findings that majority of New York City subway riders are courteous; says that in her travels as pregnant woman, she was given seat on crowded train within two stops (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A40-YEAR-OLD woman struggling to conceive a baby is told by her doctor that the quality of her eggs is poor and the lining of her uterus doesn't replenish itself well enough to sustain a pregnancy. Is she fairly average, or is she disabled? The Supreme Court ruled 5 to 4 last month that reproduction was a ''major life activity'' and that when a person's ability to reproduce is substantially limited she (or he) meets the definition of disability under the Americans With Disabilities Act.

headline.main: Ideas & Trends: Defining Disability; AIDS Virus Case Opens Door for Infertile

docs.abstract: Supreme Court ruling that reproduction is 'major life activity' discussed as to implication that the infertile may now claim rights under disability law; actual case involved suit against dentist who refused to treat woman infected with AIDS virus; Court ruled she qualifies for protection because, although not infertile, she decided not to have children for fear of passing on virus; decision may prod employers to give workers more time for infertility treatments; insurance coverage may also be affected (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The 12th World AIDS Conference ended here on Friday in a somber mood. A series of reports about new problems with anti-AIDS drugs and setbacks in vaccine trials left many participants thinking that their best hope against the epidemic was the strategy they had since it began: prevention.

headline.main: AIDS MEETING ENDS WITH LITTLE HOPE OF BREAKTHROUGH

docs.abstract: Twelfth World AIDS Conference ends in Geneva on somber note after series of reports about new problems with anti-AIDS drugs, setbacks in vaccine trials and enormous complexity of dealing with epidemic in poor countries; participants return to prevention as the most promising line of attack on AIDS, but fear that not enough is being done on such relatively simple measures as sex education, needle-exchange programs and condom distribution (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''U.N. Plans to Treat 30,000 H.I.V.-Infected Pregnant Women'' (news article, June 30): While it can be hoped that short-term AZT therapy can prevent maternal viral transmission to the fetus, applying this therapy in poor African countries, the locus of two-thirds of the AIDS epidemic, might prove to be illusory.
docs.abstract: Dr Harry M Zutz letter suggests that United Nations plan to treat HIV-infected pregnant women in Africa with AZT is laudable but impractical2

docs.lead_paragraph: For the first time, a Federal appellate court judge has upheld a state law restricting a form of late-term abortion, a ruling that conflicts with findings by other Federal judges that struck down similar laws in two other states. In a decision on Tuesday night upholding a Virginia law enacted in April barring a late-term procedure that opponents call partial-birth abortion, Judge J. Michael Luttig of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, in Richmond, reversed a Federal district judge, whose finding that the law was unconstitutional was consistent with recent appellate court decisions in Ohio and Wisconsin.

headline.main: Judge Backs Virginia Limit On Abortions

docs.abstract: Judge J Michael Luttig of Federal appeals court upholds Virginia law barring so-called 'partial-birth' abortion; ruling conflicts with findings by other Federal judges that struck down similar laws in two other states; reverses ruling by Judge Robert E Payne of US District Court (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The birth rate for unmarried black women, long a focal point in the debate over the causes of poverty among African-Americans, has reached its lowest point in 40 years, Federal health officials said today. According to figures compiled by the National Center for Health Statistics, there were 74.4 births per 1,000 unmarried black women in 1996 -- the last year for which complete data are available. That rate is significantly below the peak of 90.7 per 1,000 unmarried black women reached in 1989.

headline.main: Birth Rate Falls to 40-Year Low Among Unwed Black Women

docs.abstract: National Center for Health Statistics report finds that birth rate for unmarried black women has reached its lowest point in 40 years, 74.4 births per 1,000 unmarried black women in 1996; rate is significantly below peak of 90.7 per 1,000 unmarried black women in 1989; health officials say that increase in contraceptive use, sex education and efforts of some community groups to encourage abstention should allow trend to continue; there has been small but notable decrease in overall birth rate among unmarried women, to 44.8 per 1,000 in 1996 from 46.9 per 1,000 in 1994; that stems from drop in birth rate among unmarried white women, which had more than doubled from 1980 to 1994 before it began to drop, hitting 37.6 per 1,000 women in 1996; graph (M)
